Homage to the Buddha of Wonderful Dharma Body there, homage to the wonderful Dharma spoken by those buddhas there, homage to the thirty-two marks and eighty minor marks of those buddhas there, to the immeasurable, boundless merits.
Homage to the various Dharma assemblies of those Buddhas, the Bodhi trees, the various images, the various marvelous stupas, the wonderful places where they went, came, sat, and lay down.

Homage to those Buddhas' irreversible Dharma wheel Bodhisattva Sangha, irreversible Shravaka Sangha, Bhikshus, Bhikshunis, Upasakas, Upasikas, Devas, Nagas, Yaksas, Gandharvas, Asuras, Garudas, Kinnaras, Mahoragas, and various forms.
Having faith in the Tathagata's Dharma wheel, turning the Tathagata's Dharma wheel, the inconceivable Bodhisattva-Mahasattvas, all take refuge.

Homage to those Buddhas' ten powers, four fearlessnesses, four unobstructed knowledges, precepts, concentration, wisdom, liberation, and knowledge and insight of liberation, such immeasurable and boundless merits.
Such merits are dedicated to all sentient beings, wishing to attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
ÅšÄriputra!ğŸ”½'Take refuge in the Buddhas of the Bhadrakalpa, seventy koá¹­Ä«s in number.

One should take refuge in these innumerable and boundless Buddhas.
Good men and good women who wish to eliminate all offenses should bathe and put on new clean clothes. Reciting the names of these Buddhas and paying homage to them, they should say:

'From beginningless world systems until now, I have committed evil deeds with my body, speech, and mind, up to slandering the Vaipulya sÅ«tras and committing the five heinous crimes. May they all be extinguished.'
ÅšÄriputra!

Good men and good women who wish to fulfill the practice of the perfections, who wish to dedicate themselves to unsurpassed enlightenment, and who wish to fulfill all the perfections of bodhisattvas should say:
'I will learn from past, future, and present bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas to practice great renunciation.
Breaking open my chest and offering my heart to sentient beings, like Bodhisattva JÃ±ÄnavÄ«rya and King KÄÅ›i.
Giving away my wife and children, making offerings to the poor, like Bodhisattva Avaivartika and King AÅ›Ä«raá¹‡a, SuÂ­dÄna, and King VibhÄ«á¹£aá¹‡a.
Entering the hells to save suffering sentient beings, like Bodhisattva MahÄkÄruá¹‡ika and Prince Sunetra.
Saving sentient beings of evil conduct, like Bodhisattva SuÂ­caryÄ and King ViÅ›iá¹£á¹­acaryÄ.
Giving away the precious celestial crown on top of my head and even peeling off my scalp to give, like Bodhisattva ViÅ›iá¹£á¹­aÂ­Å›arÄ«ra and Prince RatnacÅ«á¸a.
Giving away eyes, like the bodhisattvas Beloved-to-Make and Moon-Light King and others.

Giving away ears and nose, like the bodhisattva No-Enemy and the celestial prince Victorious-Departure and others.ğŸ”½Giving away teeth, like the bodhisattva Flower-Teeth and the six-tusked elephant king and others.
Giving away tongues, like the bodhisattva Non-Retrogression and the king Good-Face and others.
Giving away hands, like the bodhisattva Always-Vigorous and the king Firm-Intent and others.
Giving away blood without regret, like the bodhisattva Dharma-Maker and the celestial prince Moon-Thought and others.
Giving away flesh and marrow, like the bodhisattva Peace-and-Security and the king Universal-Donor and others.
Giving away large and small intestines, liver, lungs, spleen, and kidneys, like the bodhisattva Good-Virtue and the king who has distanced himself from all evil and others.
Giving away body parts, large and small, like the bodhisattva Dharma-Sovereign and the celestial prince Light-Superior and others.
Giving away skin and flesh, like the bodhisattva Pure-Store and the celestial prince Golden-Color and the golden deer king and others.
Giving up fingers and toes, like the Bodhisattva Firm Effort and King Golden Color, and so forth.
Giving up fingernails and toenails, like the Bodhisattva Inexhaustible and the Heavenly Son Seeking the Good Dharma, and so forth.
For the sake of seeking the Dharma, entering a great fiery pit, like the Bodhisattva Diligent Practice and King Diligent Practice Seeking Wonderful Dharma, and so forth.
For the sake of seeking the Dharma, selling one's body, cutting open the heart, breaking the bones to extract the marrow, like the Bodhisattva Sadaprarudita and King Golden Strength, and so forth.
Enduring all suffering and distress, like the Bodhisattva Seeking Wonderful Dharma and the Great King Swift Action, and so forth.
Giving up the four continents, the great earth, and all adornments, like the Bodhisattva MahÄsthÄmaprÄpta and the Heavenly Son Moon of Supreme Merits, and so forth.
Giving up the body, like the Bodhisattva MahÄsattva and King MahÄbala, and so forth.
Giving up the body to be a servant and attendant for all poor and suffering beings, like King Åšibi, and so forth.
In brief, I also accomplish all the perfections and vows of the bodhisattvas of the past, present, and future.
In the worlds of the ten directions, I rejoice in making offerings to the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha with wonderful incense, flowers, garlands, and music.

Furthermore, I dedicate this merit to all sentient beings, wishing that by this merit, all sentient beings will not fall into evil paths, and by this merit, they will fulfill the eighty-four thousand perfections and quickly receive the prediction of unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment, quickly attain the stage of nonretrogression, and quickly accomplish unsurpassed enlightenment.'

I, sitting here, with pure and unobstructed eyes surpassing those of humans and gods, see in the east
many hundreds of Buddhas, many thousands of Buddhas, many hundreds of thousands of Buddhas, many hundreds of millions of Buddhas, many hundreds of
a thousand koá¹­is of buddhas, many hundreds of thousands of myriads of koá¹­is of nayutas of buddhas, immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeyas of buddhas,

humans, non-humans, and others, surrounding them and making offerings. I have all seen them, like observing an Ämalaka fruit in the palm of my hand.

If there are sentient beings who believe in my words and uphold and recite the names of these buddhas, they should bathe and put on new clean clothes. During the first, middle, and last parts of the day, and also during the three parts of the night, they should rise from their seats, bare one shoulder, touch their right knee to the ground, single-mindedly chant the names of these buddhas, make offerings and pay homage, and say:
'The tathÄgatas know the buddhas in the ten directions, and I now pay homage to them.'
ÅšÄriputra!
These sentient beings who make offerings and pay homage in this way will attain immeasurable merit and virtue.

If they wish to attain the stage of the Å›rÄvakas, the stage of the pratyekabuddhas, or anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi, they should pay homage to the buddhas in the ten directions, and they will all attain it.
They should also say:
'All these accumulations of merit and virtue are known by the buddhas and tathÄgatas. I dedicate them all to anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.'
